resources.string: Positive Health Check is a service mark of the U.S. Department of Health & Human Services (HHS)

Positive Health Check (PHC) uses streaming media to show a series of videos which are part of the intervention. Please connect to a local WiFi network before beginning PHC to avoid potential charges from data usage on your cellular data plan.

Positive Health Check (PHC) is a product of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC),a branch of the Department of Health and Human Services. PHC was developed for people living with HIV (PLWH) to supplement their HIV primary care provider visits. It aims to improve health outcomes of PLWH, by promoting treatment initiation, medication adherence, retention in care, sexual risk reduction, and reducing injection drug use behavior. The intervention also provides information about the prevention of mother-to-child transmission.

An interactive tool, PHC provides patients tailored information based on their responses to questions and topic selections. It was developed for patients that would like to receive additional information and strategies to support their medical care and treatment, regardless of length of time since diagnosis.

Positive Health Check is currently only accessible to patients with a valid study ID and password as provided by designated clinics working with CDC in the PHC Randomized Control Trial.

Positive Health Check (PHC) uses streaming media to show a series of videos which are part of the intervention. Please connect to a local WiFi network before beginning PHC to avoid potential charges from data usage on your cellular data plan. 

Positive Health Check was designed to help people manage HIV. The information included in Positive Health Check was developed with the input of people who have HIV, and doctors who care for them. The doctors shown in Positive Health Check are actors. 

The material embodied in this software is provided to you “AS-IS” and without warranty of any kind, express, implied or otherwise, including without limitation, any warranty of fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) or The United States (U.S.) government be liable to you or anyone else for any direct, special, incidental, indirect or consequential damages whatsoever, including without limitation, loss of use, savings or revenue, or the claims of third parties, whether or not CDC or the U.S. government has been advised of the possibility of such loss, however caused and on any theory of liability, arising out of or in connection with the possession, use or performance of this software.

CDC does not collect or store any personal information when you use Positive Health Check on any device. The study ID and password provided to PHC users by clinics participating in the PHC Randomized Control Trial, along with the intervention data, are not connected with patient names at CDC. Participating clinics maintain their own separate, secure records that allow them to connect study IDs to patients within their clinics.\n\nAdditional information about CDC’s privacy policy can be found on CDC intranet link here: http://www.cdc.gov/other/mobileprivacypolicy.html

Q: How can I get a study ID/password to access Positive Health Check?
A: Clinic staff from clinics participating in the CDC Randomized Control Trial will provide qualifying patients credentials to access Positive Health Check. 

Q: What if I can\’t remember my study ID and/or password?
A: Contact the clinic that issued your study ID/password to provide you your ID or reset password. 

Q: What should I do if the intervention freezes-up or stops working? 
A: If you are in the intervention, hit the “Refresh” button to restart content on the screen.

Q: How do I get the patient handout created by Positive Health Check if I complete the intervention outside the clinic?
A: Clinic staff will collect the patient handout printed at the clinic and place it in a secure area with your clinic records to be given to you at your next visit.

Q: Who can see the information that I provide in PHC?
A: Authorized clinic staff working on this project will be able to access information you provide in the intervention and link it to you. Other project staff outside of the clinic will be able to view information you provided in the intervention but only by your study ID (your name is not included).

Q: What if my study ID and/or password aren\’t working?
A: PHC was designed to be used by patients multiple times but no sooner than 2 months from their last visit to the intervention. If you receive the following messages, a description of the error that occurred is provided:
		· “Study ID and password don\’t match”- the password wasn\’t entered correctly.
		· “Study ID is invalid”- the Study ID entered was incorrect.
		· “Please contact clinic staff for assistance”- contact clinic staff and they will advise you of when you can log in again or activate your session. Please contact the clinic that assigned you your ID for assistance if you are unable to recall the correct study ID and/or password.

Q: I downloaded the app, but how can I join the study?
A: Only a small number of clinics were selected to work with Positive Health Check (PHC) at this time. At a later time, PHC will be assessed for broader use and access by other patients. Stay tuned.

Q: Who do I contact if I have questions about the content presented in PHC?
A: Talk with your doctor or nurse at the clinic that issued you your study ID to address any questions you may have.

Q: How do I access the Extra Info site for more information?
A: The Extra Info site is available for 7 days after you complete each intervention session. You can contact your clinic if you require specific information or assistance.
